ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Ability to read economics papers and interpret regressions
I learned how to evaluate economics papers and to read statistical output with a critical eye
Great overview of current literature in development economics.
How to read economic papers, important theories in understanding economic development, basic econometrics to critique papers
I learned a lot about economic regressions and empirical studies. I developed a much more useful and practical understanding of how economic analysis works.
I learned the structure of development and politics and developing countries.
Learned how to better analyze economic articles.
Statistics, analysis, economics

Learned about the various explanations behind what might be driving economic development divergences across different countries, and I gained a better understanding of how to read through economic studies
How to really read an economics paper.
Learning how to read economic papers! Thinking about the world in terms of regressions and statistics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: the papers are super interesting and relevant and Gerard is a super engaging professor with a refreshing perspective on what purpose economics should serve. 
Weaknesses: it's not always clear which papers are assigned which days. Sometimes it's not always feasible to read three papers before a lecture like Gerard expects, and it would be helpful to know (at least roughly) which papers were planning to cover which days. Also, the grading on the problem sets is generally lenient, but it felt super arbitrary. The grade out of 5 is supposed to correspond to a letter grade, but why not just assign a letter grade in that case?

I think that the repetition of the papers was really helpful when it came to learning how to read economics papers. No other class at Yale really emphasized them as much. I liked how Gerard would go through the paper in detail during class and really take time to spell everything out for us. I wish that we didn't only have 3 p-sets worth 40% of our grade. The grading rubric was very unclear from the start and it's rather hard to get an A in this class but an A- is very doable.
Prof is great

Strengths: Extremely well taught, interesting material, great size conducive to learning the material. 

Weaknesses: Slightly ambiguous evaluations. Felt like sometimes you weren't exactly sure what needed to be said to properly answer questions
I enjoyed the structure of the class. Strengths are the way the problem sets and exams were structured. No weaknesses.
Professor Padro was really engaging and his teaching was super clear

Strengths: Professor Padro is a phenomenal professor and a hilarious dude. Take the class to have him. 
Weaknesses: None
There could be more problem sets just to get a better sense of what was expected of us. Otherwise the material was engaging and very interesting.
Great variety of content. Thorough application of econometric concepts.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. It's a great class to get a background in political economy and the origins of economic development. A lot of the papers we read really changed how I view (global) politics, and I've found them to be super relevant in other political science classes like Comparative Politics and upper level econ.
Of course! This is a phenomenal course that teaches students how to interpret economics papers. One of the best classes I have taken at Yale.

I'd recommend it if you're interested in development and want to develop the skill of reading economics papers. It's interesting to see the real work that economists do and to delve into papers rather than relying on newspaper headlines to learn about the cutting edge
Light workload and fair exams! Take it if you have basic econometrics/statistics - will help you be a lot better at reading and interpreting econ literature
Yes 100%. if you have any interest in developmental econ this is the course for you. terrific intro course to understanding why econ degrees are useful (not for finance)
I would. Love the professor.
Yes!! A great opportunity to practice applying empirical methods to influential papers on economic development
Yes! I learned a lot about statistics and I really liked the professor
Absolutely. The professor is awesome, the lecture material is interesting, and the workload is manageable. What else do you want in a yale class?
Yes! You develop a better understanding of the practical applications of econometric methods and these examples are very interesting.
Yes-- understanding econometrics is vital for any economic thinker. This builds on what you learn in Econ 117 in a brilliant, relatively low-workload way.
I think this course was quite interesting. We learned about a number of different countries and analyzed the influence of different groups on the economic growth of countries.
